SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: Which theme is best supported by paragraphs 10 through 13 in the story?

A.Choice: Change can sometimes take people by surprise.

B.Choice: Brothers often enjoy doing the same things.

C.Choice: Family activities can be fun for everyone.

D.Choice: Every family has its own way of doing things.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: What do the details in paragraphs 3 and 14 show about Trent?

A.Choice: Trent is not worried about his brother's feelings until Troy is upset.

B.Choice: Trent would rather be measured later when he has had more time to grow.

C.Choice: Trent would rather spend time on his birthday having fun by himself.

D.Choice: Trent is not interested in his height until he learns that he is taller than Troy.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words, phrases, figurative language, and academic and content-specific words.
Content: In paragraph 18, what does it mean when the narrator says, “I wanted to lay this matter to rest ...”?

A.Choice: He wants to know the truth.

B.Choice: He is tired after many activities.

C.Choice: He needs time to get ready for bed.

D.Choice: He is worried that his father is busy.

SubTopics: Explain how claims in a text are supported by relevant reasons and evidence.
Content: Which detail from the story shows the best evidence for the claim that Trent is taller than Troy?

A.Choice: “ ... Trent trotted to the doorway and stood up against the jamb.” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “The red mark was indeed a little higher than the blue.” (paragraph 13)

C.Choice: “Trent and I turned and stepped backwards towards each other.” (paragraph 20)

D.Choice: “ ... hands rested on each of our heads, keeping us in place.” (paragraph 22)

SubTopics: In literary texts, identify parts of stories, dramas, and poems using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza. In informational texts, identify and use text features to build comprehension.
Content: How is the information in paragraph 37 important to the story?

A.Choice: It compares the feelings of two main characters.

B.Choice: It explains the cause and the effect of a problem.

C.Choice: It tells why the setting is important to the events.

D.Choice: It explains how the conflict in the story is settled.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: Which detail would be best to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: Trent is excited about his new fish.

B.Choice: Trent's mark on the door is higher than Troy's.

C.Choice: Troy is tired of being measured on his birthday.

D.Choice: Troy's hair is different than Trent's.

SubTopics: Discuss how the reader's point of view or perspective may differ from that of the author, narrator or characters in a text.
Content: What does Rupa most likely think about saris at the beginning of the story?

A.Choice: She thinks that grandmothers wear saris but that young women should not.

B.Choice: She thinks that saris are pretty but would not want to wear one every day.

C.Choice: She thinks that saris are only worn on special days and are not good for every day.

D.Choice: She thinks that people wear saris because they are helpful but not comfortable.

SubTopics: Explain how claims in a text are supported by relevant reasons and evidence.
Content: How does Dadima best support her claim that she never gets tired of wearing saris?

A.Choice: She shows that many of her saris are very beautiful.

B.Choice: She gives examples of things a sari can be used for.

C.Choice: She explains that her own grandmother wore saris.

D.Choice: She is able to dress her granddaughters in her own saris.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Why does Dadima show the girls some of her saris?

A.Choice: She wants to teach her granddaughters how to wrap a sari to wear it correctly.

B.Choice: She wants to show her granddaughters how to choose a sari that will look good.

C.Choice: She wants to share special memories from her life with her granddaughters.

D.Choice: She wants to give her granddaughters a chance to play dress up with pretty clothes.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words, phrases, figurative language, and academic and content-specific words.
Content: In paragraph 29, the phrase “unfold and unfold and unfold some more” suggests that

B.Choice: the sari is tied in knots

SubTopics: Recognize genres and make connections to other texts, ideas, cultural perspectives, eras, personal events, and situations.
Content: Sometimes people have customs of wearing special clothing for certain occasions. Which detail from the story best connects to this idea?

A.Choice: Dadima shows the girls the saris that she wore on important days in her life.

B.Choice: Dadima helps the girls put on saris so they can look more like her.

C.Choice: Dadima explains how saris are helpful and can be used to stay comfortable.

D.Choice: Dadima tells the girls that her own grandmother's grandmother also wore saris.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] My Dadima Wears a Sari,” how do Rupa's thoughts about wearing a sari change in the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: How do the details in paragraphs 8 through 13 support a theme of “[Excerpt from] My Dadima Wears a Sari”? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: What do the details in paragraphs 7 and 12 show about the baby-sitter?

A.Choice: The baby-sitter has a good idea.

C.Choice: The baby-sitter knows Billy very well.

SubTopics: In literary texts, identify parts of stories, dramas, and poems using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza. In informational texts, identify and use text features to build comprehension.
Content: How does paragraph 6 connect to paragraph 16 in the story?

A.Choice: The paragraphs show the cause and effect of the storm.

B.Choice: The paragraphs reveal how the narrator changes over time.

C.Choice: The paragraphs compare the characters' feelings.

D.Choice: The paragraphs show a problem and the solution.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words, phrases, figurative language, and academic and content-specific words.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 21 of the story.
:box:It also rattles his nerves.
What is the meaning of the phrase “rattles his nerves”?

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: How does Billy feel about the baby-sitter's ideas for what to do during the thunderstorm?

A.Choice: Billy likes the ideas so much that he wants him to come back again.

B.Choice: Billy thinks that the ideas are not as much fun as other games.

C.Choice: Billy believes that the ideas are so silly that he jokes about them later.

D.Choice: Billy is confused about the ideas and asks his parents to explain them.

SubTopics: Discuss how the reader's point of view or perspective may differ from that of the author, narrator or characters in a text.
Content: From whose point of view is the story told?

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: Which statement best shows a central idea of the story?

A.Choice: Doing other things can make scary events easier.

B.Choice: Hiding when you are afraid can make you feel better.

C.Choice: Making new friends is easy when you make up games together.

D.Choice: Practicing any skill is important when you want to improve.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize portions of a text.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] The Sensory System: Why Am I Ticklish?,” what is a central idea of the first two paragraphs? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: In literary texts, describe character traits, motivations, or feelings, drawing on specific details from the text. In informational texts, describe the relationship among a series of events, ideas, concepts, or steps in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] The Sensory System: Why Am I Ticklish?,” how does the nose work to help people? Use two details from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Explain how claims in a text are supported by relevant reasons and evidence.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] The Sensory System: Why Am I Ticklish?,” how does the author support the claim she makes in paragraph 16? Use two details from the passage to support your response.
